Let me first say that if you are expecting Kairo to be something along the lines of Myst, Riven or, for that matter, any challenging puzzler, do not buy. The puzzles lack depth, complexity, and do not require deep thinking in order to discover the solution. They feel like an afterthought and I think the developer intentionally designed them so to make the experience in Kairo more fluid.

As you may have read, Kairo is a minimalist exploration game (though it's more of an abstract art gallery simulator). Meaning you can only walk, run, and jump. Your interaction with machines is restricted thus partially explaining the lack of depth in some of the puzzles. No in game button prompts. Nothing out of the Kairo's context distracts you, save the notification that informs you've solved a puzzle. It's all for the purpose of pulling you deep into Kairo's world full of abstract architecture and objects with strange behavior that apparently defies physics. The fine grain filter and errie soundtrack assist in attempting to build an absorbing atmosphere.

Except I felt a disconnect for some reason. None of the abstract architectures (nor the atmosphere) evoked any feelings. No texts located anywhere to provide some backstory. Perhaps (and I'm not sure) some story could be deciphered (or interpreted) but the game gave me no reason or motivation to invest the effort into it. Even during the conclusion when Kairo's purpose was hinted at, no tingle of emotion.

In my opinion, you can approach this game like you approach a strange dream right after waking up, either invest the energy to interpret it and derive personal meaning or instantly forget about all the vague disjointed images. If you're the former or if the idea of an abstract art gallery simulator sounds appealing, then maybe Kairo might be for you.

However, if you are looking for something with cohesion and a game that gradually unfolds a story with clarity (or a challenging puzzler as talked about in first paragraph) then I would defintely pass this one up.

Graphics:
I could not shake off the feeling that all those duplicated cubes with the exact same texture were not a bold artistic design, but rather a result of laziness. Overall it felt extremely cheap --- You could say that it's fitting since the game is really cheap. That last remark aside, I would have preferred a smaller, but more polished world.

Puzzles:
The puzzles are never really satisfying to solve. There are mostly button-pressing chores, that you find yourself solving for not particular reasons. After playing for a while, I just wanted to get done with them as quickly as possible, which I guess defeats the purpose of the game...

This game puts you into an existential crisis.


11/10 would cower into a corner and start crying again

Kairo isn't a game for everybody.  In fact, I wouldn't even say it was a game for most people.  It's the type of game that takes a lot of patience to enjoy.  You've got to really put yourself into the game, imagine that you're really in this place, seeing these things.  The atmosphere and mystery are everything, and if that isn't your bag then you won't find enough to enjoy here when it comes to pure gameplay.

There are indeed puzzles to be solved, but most of them are quite simple.  There are no controls beyond moving around and jumping, and there's no text or story to speak of beyond what you're observing of your environment.  As is to be expected with these types of games, a lot of it is open for interpretation, including the ending.  The graphics are solid, but quite simple and low-budget; most of the architecture is made up of blocks and flat planes.

If any of those things are deal-breakers, then don't even bother.  But if you're into the pure sense of discovery that games can offer then I can't possibly recommend it enough.  The term gets tossed around a lot, but it truly is more of an experience than a game.  You've got to like abstraction, simplicity, and rich atmosphere (thanks in large part to the excellent sound design).  You've got to be the type of person who gets a thrill from the simple act of booting up a game and not knowing exactly what to expect--of heading through a door and not having the foggiest idea of what you'll see.

There isn't much more to say about the game.  If it's not your cup of tea, nothing else here will be relevant to you.  If it is, then there's no need for me to explain what was great about it with more detail, because it's already obvious that you should play it.  I mean hey, it's five bucks, and as I type this it's on sale for one whole dollar.  Even if the story only lasts a few hours, that's a stupidly good deal for such an experience.

Pretty frustrated with the game at first, and I ended up marathoning it to 100% completion.  Took about 6 hours total, with breaks.  Puzzles are fun, albiet some of them are kinda frustrating.  I ended up just guessing on one of them to get it.\n\nVERY recommended, but keep in mind it's an adventure puzzle game before picking it up.  Well worth the money, imo.

reviewText:
A wonderfully cryptic game. Kairo's world is a foreboding, mysterious and somewhat creepy place, yet one that will reside in your memory for a long time.
The gameplay is largely based on exploration and relatively straightforward puzzle-solving, and the game does not take a whole lot of time to finish.
Despite the apparently 'cold' exterior, Kairo actually builds to a poignant ending - if you have the time to explore all of the secrets and secret rooms, and can put the pieces together, you will be rewarded with an interesting implied narrative. Note that the game has no exposition at all, so it's all very subtle.
The answer does not lie within the secret ending - it lies in all of the game.

Kairo is worth the time and the little money it asks, especially if you're into adventure and first-person puzzlers.

reviewText:
I unfortunately got this game just days before it went on sale, but at full price it still felt like an amazing deal.  Imagine LSD: Dream Emulator but texturally subdued and transformed into a relatively linear puzzle game, with just a dash of the Assassin's Creed 2 glyph sequences for flavor.

The graphics and designs of the game are unimpressive, but not uninentionally so.  The minimalism of both the visuals and the music create a complexly desolate atmosphere, and, like LSD, the emptiness of the world never comes off as a result of laziness but of tasteful restraint.  It's easy to fill a puzzle game with distracting elements that intrude on the experience as a whole, but it's refreshing to see one that makes an enjoyable experience using only movement controls and basic graphics.

In the vein of games like Fract OSC, Antichamber, The Devil's Tuning Fork, and Against the Wall, this is a game that does not hold the player's hand at any point and does not even provide any form of communication or instruction to the player until the ending, allowing for total uninterrupted exploration, and the game is intuitive enough to keep going at a steady pace regardless.  This makes sense in an internal way, as well, as the game is set in a long abandoned universe in which the player is a complete stranger.

The ending is a bit cheesy and the sequences that reveal the world's story are unoriginal at best.  I was also unimpressed by the various photographs and videos that attempted to connect Kairo to Earth, which appear incessantly throughout the game just incase the message wasn't received the first few times.  In a puzzle game that involves some amount of thought in order to progress, this felt patronizing and undermined the feeling that the game developer trusts the player to make the connections themselves.  The alien and deserted tone of the game was also diminished by this forced message, which left me wishing that the game had remained mysterious and totally detached from the real world like it initially appeared.  It seems as if the game was created first, but in the later stages of development the developer decided to tack a deeper story onto the game, conflicting with the original vision for the project.

Bland connotations aside, I didn't expect to spend nine hours in this game, and it says something about Kairo that I can spend a day backtracking through every area multiple times in order to unlock the achievements and the secret ending and still have fond memories of the experience (even if the secret ending was a massive disappointment).

Ultimately, I would recommend this game if you want something that has a poweful and moving atmosphere, but if you're just looking for a puzzle game then look elsewhere, as the puzzles here aren't as memorable as the overarching experience.

reviewText: I really wanted to like Kairo but there is too much wrong with it for me to enjoy. The game doesn't make it clear when it saves and it doesn't give you the option to save whenever you want. This resulted in me completing major puzzles of the game and then leaving only to come back days later and realize that twenty minutes of work was gone. The player also moves to slow for some of the larger room puzzles which means correcting mistakes is a pain and bother. The only thing I really liked about the game was the lack of a HUD although at times this meant that I had no idea what to do since there was never any instructions. Honestly, a quick save feature would have made me love this game or at the very least an icon that shows when the game is saving but with neither of those things, I would highly recommend you avoid this game.

reviewText:
I was completely blown away by this game given it's price and the fact that it appears, from the screenshots, to be something created in a few hours, but don't let that fool you, this game is one of the best examples of game design I've ever seen.

Atmosphere/Story/Game World I can honestly say I don't think I've ever played a game with half as much atmosphere as Kairo, and the fact that it does it with the most basic of graphics, no voice acting, no back story, no cinematics, and no supporting characters is astounding. Everything, the soundtrack, the mysterious, blocky architecture, the vast empty spaces, the grain filter over everything, even the floaty controls, all of it feels deliberate and just drips with atmosphere and conveys the story in a way that is far more compelling than any amount exposition ever could be. It is so immersive, if you allow it to be, that it will actually make the hair on your neck and arms stand on end and your skin crawl, in a good way, even for someone who dislikes the entire horror genera. You know you're alone but you just can't shake the feeling that something is off, that you're being watched. I imagine this is exactly how you'd feel if you were exploring an empty, foreign world in real life. It taps straight into your human nature, you have this creepy feeling but you have to keep going, you have to learn more about this world and what happened. Truly amazing.

There are some bugs or places where it isn't as polished as some titles. The biggest issue is that can see through geometry when you stand right next to it. There were also some places that I wasn't sure if there was a graphical error or just a design choice. Mainly places that seemed like there was a floor, I could walk and jump, but I appeared to be walking in space. Overall pretty polished.

Puzzles/Exploration Yet another place where Kairo shines. None of the main puzzles are that hard, you may need the hints in the menu for one or two, but the way that they are presented is the epitome of good puzzle design. The full extent of each puzzle is usually not fully apparent when you enter a room but the game does a brilliant job of teaching" you the rules as you try and solve it. You probably won't solve it the first time but the penalty for failing is very small

reviewText: The creepiest game I've ever played, but the only creepy one I've actually liked.  The way Kario creates puzzle solving completely through player movement is pure genius, and the odd machines and structures of this world are awe-inspiring.  The world of Kario will be in my mind forever, even if I don't know it.  I haven't have any dreams about it yet, but I'm sure there there will be remanants of it, deliberate and accidental, in everything I do from now on.\nPurely moving, disturbing, and amazing.

reviewText:
If you have ever went on a walk, in an empty gymnasium with your eyes closed, you probably would find Kairo boring in comparison. In Kairo you get to do a lot of walking. I think. Actually I have no idea what this game actually IS.... When I am playing it, I feel as though I'm stuck in Half Life's tram car, able to look around, move a little, but nothing actually happens.
Actually that's a bit generous. It's more like waiting for your girlfriend to come downstairs for your date - you can walk around, check out the books on her book shelf, look at the dirt on the floor... all with an anticipation that she would be coming down stairs ANY minute,., She never does - and THAT's Kairo's entire gameplay model.
Did I like it? I can't say, I never actually DID anything. Oh sure, doors opened, things clicked, but unless I'm missing the point, the entire purpose of this game is to show how nicely you can make big ugly square blocks look sometimes.
I'd like to see what the developer actually intended, some day.

column19: there are a bunch of pedestals that make sounds. If you look up
column20: you see stars above them that have lines drawn on them from the last 4 pedestals... and no indication of what you should do. It has a triangle in the middle that is aligned and shaped without matching the stars
column21: so there is no indication which of the many triangle shapes you should be making
column22: or if that is even the correct thing to do. I spent probably 20 minutes making various triangles in that room
column23: to no avail.\n\nIn another area
column24: there were what looked like a lot of pods that had screens on them. Most of the screens had static
column25: but one showed a low-res version of what you were seeing
column26: and a couple others showed something else. The significance of this place was totally lost on me.\n\nAlso hidden in the game are tiny symbol things you can collect for... no known reason at all. They seem to largely be hidden in various rooms
column27: so trying to collect those turns into the "look very closely at every wall from every angle" sort of thing... it was getting tedious.\n\nThe "world" is also very minimal. It is just a bunch of separate "rooms" with portals connecting them. There is no real plot to be found
column28: no idea why any of this exists
column29: who you are supposed to be

reviewText:
What am I even doing?

Kairo is a very beautiful and ambient puzzle game with zero help and is the complete opposite of linear. It had puzzles and walking parts that have no connection and will leave you completely lost 95% of the way, some people may like that but it was a massive turn off for me. I used a guide for most of the game just so I could get it finished and write this review.

My girlfriend tried it so I could make sure it wasent just me not knowing what I was doing, shes very puzzle smart and gets these kinda things really easily, but she became frustrated at the lack of help you are given. Most of the puzzles have no logical conclusion and will just make you guess forever until you figure it with just blind luck and perserverence.

What it does right is make a story and really get the feeling of mystery and uncertainty embeded into the entire experience.

With a guide it took me 3.5 hours to complete, without I would say if you didn't go insane already and forgot what time even is it will take 10+

I really wanted to recommend this game, I bought it on sale thinking it was going to be this amazing ambient adventure with clear colours and pretty shapes but I really can't, it just makes no sense.

It had promise and if it had just a little help to give you it would of been three times the game it is, but all I experienced was a mess of beautiful art.

Personal Rating: 2/5

reviewText:
When I saw the screenshots and such for Kairo I presumed that Kairo may not be the most visually appealing game but sometimes, while such games may not always put their best screenshots on display, they do usually have some redeeming charm. The various positive reviews and an endorsement from RPS also seemed to indicate that this was a diamond in the rough. However as it turned out, it is actually a mouldy chunk of food in the dust. How on earth this game achieved anywhere near a positive status on Steam I have no idea, but I suspect foul play. Allow me to explain why you need to avoid Kairo like the plague.

Plain textures can sometimes be compensated for by some impressively detailed architecture or environments which hold intrigue. Kairo simply does not have any of that. The environments look like they were made by someone experimenting with mapping and decided to package everything together to make it seem like a game. The designer has some strange idea that throwing tons of fog into every section of the game is a substitute for creating atmospheric lighting or using the environment itself to influence the players' state of mind. As such every part of the game I saw felt lifeless, unfinished and bland. I have honestly seen maps from the original Quake with more atmosphere, style and imagination.

The 'puzzles' are so dull that I literally gave up after playing the game for half an hour. They consist of running into invisible triggers or standing on trigger brushes to cause something to happen. One of the things the designer forgot to actually do is clearly indicate when a puzzle is solved and what the point of solving it was. In one area I found 4 platforms which turned on a bunch of particle effects on a rotating central disc. Visually quite interesting and clearly the puzzle was solved because all of the triggers stopped working, but it did not appear to have any effect upon the game. The lack of direction here is astounding as the designer chooses to leave you completely in the dark as to what you should be doing and gives no context or sense of progress to what you manage to figure out on your own. Someone needs to sit this person down with games like Myst, the Longest Journey, Master Reboot or even The Room so they can understand the difference between an enjoyable mystery and aimless activity.

Kairo is unpleasant to look at, boring to explore, devoid of any sense of achievement or purpose and ultimately one of the worst games I have had the misfortune to mistake for a worthwhile investment of money or time.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Take a 90's shooter, skip on plot, guns and enemies. What you're left with is a bunch of unengaging puzzles which are only worthy of changing the pace between other gameplay elements, of which there are none now. Such puzzles consist of stepping on floor buttons in the correct order, shown on a wall in front of you. Levels are extremely low-poly and have single featureless texture tiled over most surfaces. Monochromatic environments, while making up for an appealing screenshot gallery, can be really nauseating.

In order to have a minimalist aesthetic appeal Kairo strives for, it would have to do all those small things right, like making footstep sounds actually match your walking speed, or not having them at all. Instead, its one of those games where you feel like you're stuck crouching constantly so you hit the crouch button to untoggle it, but the camera drops even lower.

reviewText:
Very strange, very mysterious, but also incredibly beatiful.

There is no introduction, no talking, nobody to hold your hand.
There are no tools and no weapons.
There is nothing but your natural human ability to walk, jump, push things and think.
And yet you almost always know what to do.
The world is silently guiding you through its majesty and testing your lateral thinking as you go.

The charm of this game comes from the simplicity of the controls, the great design of the environment and the sheer amount of mystery flowing through every room.

reviewText: I didn't like Kairo. It feels unfinished. And the blinding white sky and strange visual appearance kind of give me a headache. The game doesn't teach well at all, so you feel unsure of what you should be doing. It is not nearly linear enough, and has no sense of accomplishment. I purchased it because it looked so promising, but the game fails to deliver. I hate to write a negative review, but this game is just not well put together or polished. The levels don't have a consistent feel or visual style, the architecture is not believable, navigation is difficult and the player just needs a LOT more direction.\n\nIf the game was linear, taught skills incrementally, was more intuitive, rewarded the player, had save points, and was easier to navigate it could be a really fun game. But it doesn't quite do what a game should. It has a lot of potential, though, and it is too bad that it isn't more finished.

reviewText:
I don't think I've ever regretted spending $5.

I put a little under an hour and a half into this game before I made the decision to uninstall it.

Here is my reasoning.

I bought the game because some reviewers touted its similarity to Antichamber, a game that is very near and dear to my heart. The trailer for the game made it appear tantalizing and intriguing and, most of all, fun.

Unfortunately, it didn't take me twenty minutes to regret this small purchase.

Kairo has, I've found, missed the mark on one of the most fundamental gaming concepts; not just in video games, but in the entire realm of playing a game for fun. I call this carrot-and-stick". Other people call this other things. But essentially
date: in nearly every game you can think of
hoursPlayed: your objective
helpfulPercent: what keeps you from your objective. I could cite endless games
votesHelpful: card games
votesTotal: board games
votesFunny: arcade games
commentsCount: games of make-believe played in the backyard of my friends' houses when we were five
column16: and
column17: yes
column18: video games that keep/kept me latched onto the idea
column19: entertained
column20:
and engaged in the gameplay.

One thing I quickly learned in Kairo is that there's not much of a carrot.

I'm going to take this discussion back to Antichamber
column21: for those who have played it. I'd hypothesize that the two are compared often for the similar concept of working through puzzles in complete solitude. But in the Hub of Antichamber
column22: you can see a door marked Exit
column23: though you cannot reach it. In one of the first spawn points
column24: you can see a door behind a barrier marked "The End". There's even the Black Ghost
column25: dancing just out of your reach on certain puzzles. These are all suitable carrots.\n\nKairo is designed in such a way that I have yet to see the carrot; there's not much more than an endless stick. And after almost an hour and a half of playing for no apparent reason
column26: I tired of the game.\n\nOn one last note
column27: for all the endless puzzles in Kairo
column28: there are worlds you walk through that have no puzzles at all. The game has a hint feature
column29: but if you are not so inclined to use it
column30: it's incredibly difficult to discern a puzzle world from a world that's apparently there for your exhaustive visual pleasure."

reviewText:
Before I begin, I have played for more than 0.3 hours, but I played in offline mod. Not very much though, this game made me bored faster than a math lesson can do.


Positives:

- Decent scripting I guess

Negatives:

- Pretty much everything
- Boring gameplay
- No storyline


You spawn in a world with absoutely no clue how you got there. You don't have a name, you don't have a goal, you don't have anything to find. The story is non existing.

Some games can be good even without a clear goal or a background story, but not in this case.

Not only do you have no goal, enemies or purpose in Kairo whatsoever, the puzzles are also simple but yet confusing. You can not interact with anything and you don't have an inventory, meaning that all you can do is move objects by walking towards them, or jump on random platforms in hope that something will happen. Really, really simple puzzles. And when I say it's also confusing, what I mean is, you don't really know why you are doing what you are doing due to the non existing story and the few hints you get doesn't really help that much at all.


Do I recommend this game? No. I don't recommend it to anyone.

People that love adventures, no. The game is as simple as it can be (including the soundtracks and gameplay in general) with nothing to explore or discover at all. You don't even have a purpose or anything to lose. Not even health (no, you can't even die in this game).

People that like puzzle games, no. Again, the puzzles are basic, yet confusing, and you don't really know why you are doing them.

People that love a good storyline, no. There is no story in this game at all.

-------------------

Why people like this is beyond me. I have played many bad games, but this without doubt in my top 5 most boring games ever.

2/10 - Really bad
voteText: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
As someone who used to work with mapping for garry's mod I can clearly see that the mapping in this game is terrible. Another problem is that the controls are inexplicably sluggish and you feel as if you're on ice skates while you walk. I thought it might be because of my computer but the framerate is very good and there is no mouse lag so the problem has to be related to the game.
Now, I understand that this game is inspired by yume nikki, but that is no excuse to make the puzzles so obscure without a hint on how to solve them. yume nikki itself was not a finished game you know. All in all, I want to get immersed into the game but the lack of polish and sluggish controls make it impossible to do so.

Until this game is properly polished I can't recommend it.

If the dev wants help with mapping, I would be willing to help if I can, for a small fee of course.

This is a pretty interesting game. Though oftentimes it suffers from the same problem as similar indie titles. It'll forget it's an abstract first person puzzle game and become Sculpture Garden Simulator 2015. Yes game, when walk through your rooms I appreciate your post-modernist, minimalist design that recalls Egyptian, Chinese and Classical art. But when you place these puzzle-less rooms in between the puzzles, you're really hurting the pacing. Though for $0.74 (as of this writing) , I definitely recommend picking it up. The puzzles are just challenging enough and if you have trouble the game has a pretty generous hint system.

Kairo is beautiful, plain and simple. It is an adventure from the begining. Not because of the adrenaline injections most games rely on and many gamers are addicted to. Bad fanfiction aside, this game is pure genius and I want all of my friends to play it.

This has been quite an experience.  I wasn't expecting nearly so much out of a little game I picked up on a whim.

According to walkthroughs, Kairo can be finished in just a half an hour if you know what you're doing, but I spent hours going through it.  The puzzles are indeed difficult at times, but what slowed me down the most was just stopping to gawk at the architecture.  It's just simple geometry and the textures are concrete, concrete and more concrete, yet somehow it's really amazing to look at.  The intense colored lighting and sheer emptiness of the massive, enigmatic spaces you get to wander through really hit with impact.  What really makes the environment pull you in though is the music.  Kairo has by far some of the best ambient background music I've ever heard.  Definitely play with good headphones if you've get 'em.  I'm officially starting my Steam category of games to go back and play again when the Oculus Rift comes out.

It's really difficult to describe the unique feeling and atmosphere of Kairo's world, but here's the best I can do:  Does anyone remember the bizarre, abstract and often borderline incoherent art-house style computer animation that occasionally showed up on TV in the late 80s and early 90s?  It's like that, but with more thinking.

Gameplay consists mostly of puzzles and exploration, and both are quite rewarding.  A lot of the puzzle give that sort of Myst vibe at first glance (ie. here are some random shapes and levers
date: have fun and see you in a couple hours")  but I found all of them to be fair and some were even a bit intuitive.  There were several that seemed totally abstract like they should have been frustrating to figure out
recommended: and I'm not sure if I just got lucky but the answers always clicked in my head after a bit of twiddling.  With so many puzzle types being redone to death in adventure games
hoursPlayed: it's good to see some totally new concepts that work.  My only real gripe with the puzzles are the fake ones.  Or at least apparently fake ones; I'm really not sure.  There were several rooms I faffed about in for ages before pulling up the in-game hint system to find out the room was just "here to play around with
voteText: mostly."  Mostly?  That's just lovely.  There were two places I recall getting this "hint"
helpfulPercent: and they were the only two places I had to resort to using the hint system.  And then the hint is basically "this room is just here to waste your time. OR IS IT?"  Oh just ♥♥♥♥ off and tell me
votesHelpful: is it or is it not a room with no purpose?  Again
votesTotal: just a minor gripe since I moved on when I got the aforementioned hint.\n\nThere were a few other minor nitpicks I had after finishing the game
votesFunny: but nothing major.  There were some pretty glaring geometry glitches like hairline cracks
commentsCount: overlapping brushwork
column16: misaligned textures
column17: missing faces
column18: and gaps that looked like they weren't supposed to be there.  Higher resolution textures could have really improved the look of a few areas too in my opinion.  Finally
column19: while I loved the music throughout the game itself

column21: but it was jarringly different from everything heard up to that point which I think detracted a bit from the final sequence.  Just my opinion.  Again
column22: all minor things not worth too much thought.\n\nAll in all
column23: Kairo is a unique concept with some changelling puzzles and a fun bit of easter egg hunting

reviewText:
Kairo is a beautifully eerie shapescape that combines original style with familiar puzzle questing.  It is a simple yet aw- filled atmospheric journey that takes place in this supernatural-like world you've stumbled upon.

Pros:
+ Increadible atmosphere.  Sometimes even daunting to look at with the great depth of field use by the dev.
+ Music is more like a drone in various keys and melodies.  It's unique and quite pleasing to listen to.
+ There is no linearity to it, well there is but you're free to tackle various areas at your leisure.
+ Puzzles are both easy and incredibly challenging.
+ Sandbox style freedom to explore the world.  It's not very large but the amount of rooms can make you forget where to go or where you've been.

Cons:
- There is very little if any backstory but some may say none is needed with just how odd and abstract the setting is.
- Some puzzles are a little too tough because they go completely unexplained or not elluded to.

Overall I would rate this game a solid 8/10.  If you're into puzzles and don't mind exploring abstract scenery with no AI interaction then this game is 100% worth it at it's price.  On sale even better.  I highly recommend it.

YES
ANOTHER PUZZLE GAME

now with a creepy/soothing/mysterious soundtrack.

And no guns!

and VR support!

and how cool is that...

no? Ah, screw you. This game is not like to know, but is to experience.
(like what those others say in their own way though.)

It's a very simple exploring game, don't expect thrills or flashes of excitement. But the story is rich if you take the time to feel it out. Very atmospheric and enjoyable. Some puzzles are difficult enough to make it a true challenge. I've bought copies for most of my friends to give it a try and they've all enjoyed it as well (or at least told me as much). Definitely my favorite.

What a fantastic game. Smooth gameplay, intriguing storyline, simple atmosphere, and yet challenging . Definitely a game I would recommend to a friend. 10/10
I loved that I never felt rushed to complete any of the puzzles and that I never felt that you needed a trick" to complete a puzzle (only looked at a walkthrough guide twice on first playthrough). Observation is your best friend in the game. Its nice to know you can go back to the begining at any point to recheck for runes or secrets missed.
There are no real negatives as I thoroughly enjoyed the game. Some people might find it a bit short but finding ALL secrets will take a bit of effort.
All-in-all a game I glad I took the time to play."

Kairo was an amazing game, from its beautiful scenery to the helpful message at the end. I found it quite spooky being alone the entire time, but it certainly gave it a sense of wonder and the feeling of emptiness. I was kinda iffy about this game at first and some of the puzzles are tricky, but the atmosphere and the soundtrack are absolutely worth it.\nThe soundtrack absolutely helps the game and its amazingly eerie. If you want the soundtrack, you can get it on iTunes for $10.

Really creepy puzzle game! There are in-game hints for the puzzles, which I thought was nice (there's a hint section in the menu that only gives hints for puzzles). The story is really well done and subtle enough to not get in the way for people more interested in the puzzle aspect.

Only 2 gripes: the game's pretty linear/straightforward so IDK how much replay value there is to get the achievements, and there's a puzzle where for me the in-game hint system was completely unhelpful, so I had to just mess around until it solved

It's a cheap, short, interesting game that you can beat in a few hours, so I'd rec it

Too blocky, chunky and minimal for me. Has potential, but after 10 min I knew I'd had enough.\n\nThat's not to say it's terrible. I don't want to not recommend it". There needs to be a middle ground where you neither recommend for or against. It depends what sort of games you like and what mood you're in. Sometimes a basic and minimal game is exactly the thing to get into. Right now I'm distracted by The Talos Principle... expensive but good."

Decided to buy this game since it was on sale for $1. I feel like this game is worth the cheap price because it isn't an impressive game. This game is complex, confusing and movement seemed a little slow to me. I love puzzle games, but this wasn't my cup of tea.
Cheap,good music , calming gameplay , mistic places, and Great puzzles!
A great game experience.  You look you move.  You solve puzzles.  Very minimal and artistic.  The audio is VERY well done.

reviewText: Stark environments and fun puzzles. I really enjoyed the abstract presentation.
Maybe I'm paranoid, as far as I know there are no enemies in this games, but I fear for my life constantly, every corner hides an unknown terror... liking it so far.
Oculus dk2 support please!

As an abstract puzzle game, Kairo is great.  The gameplay is simple yet challenging, and the built-in hint system is helpful enough to point you in the right direction when you're stuck without outright spoiling the puzzle.  However, I think the abstract design makes the story hard to follow (and leaves the player to guess); after finishing the game, I wasn't really sure what it was all about.  Still, that doesn't detract from the gameplay.  If you enjoy puzzle games and want something a little different, I would definitely recommend Kairo.

Pros:
- Otherworldly/alien environment.
- Engaging, abstract, and unique puzzles.
- Good music, which helps set a somewhat ominous and somber tone.

Cons:
- The story was a little *too* abstract.
- Keyboard controls are not remappable, or even listed in full.  For example, the R" key resets you to the room entrance
date: but I found that completely by accident.\n- There is no way to see your progress on collecting the hidden glyphs

This game is not primarily a puzzle game. There is so little to interact with on the map. The graphics are so simple and washed out.  Imagine yourself wandering up and down the corridors of the bleak screenshots you see, and that is pretty much the main point of the game. I really tried to get something out of it, but what a bleak depressing boring game. I tried to warn you.

Kairo is really one of a kind game. It takes a little time to absorb you into its world, but once it does it never lets you leave it. It's an adventure/puzzle game which is kind of easy to finish but extremely hard to master.

There is so much hidden stuff in this game that you'll want to play it again and again. Yet, none of its puzzles is obvious or easy to be seen.

Kairo's alien world is extrordinary unique and beautiful on its own and feels like it came out from 2001's monolith.

I bought this on sale for less than 1€, but I'd happily have paid the full price for it. it's an extremely minimalistic game, don't buy it if you absolutely need captivating plots, high-end graphics and complex gameplay or you'd be disappointed. the game is a fascinating journey through a beautifully designed surrealistic world. a really fitting ambient soundtrack adds a lot to the experience. if you've ever played Hiversaires and enjoyed it you'll really like this game as well (if you haven't go and play it). despite the 90s-like 3d graphics I was more than once amazed by the haunting and eerie scenarios and architecture of the game. along the journey you have to solve puzzles to proceed, which are decent, full of satisfying eureka-moments and quite never frustrating. it's a pretty short game tho, it took me less than 3 hours to get to the final credits, but still there were a couple of optional puzzles I didn't solve and some secrets I discovered that suggest there is something more if you find them all, so I might get back to it one day. one last note: most of the negative reviews complain about the lack of a plot and clear instructions. well I liked that instead, it's a plot device itself that adds to the unsettling feel of the game. you're thrown in without any explanation and are left with more questions than answers. picture it as a dream, no one is there to tell you where you are, what is happening and what you have to do, you just accept it and go on, and it's beautiful that way.\n\noverall solid 7.5/10, would play again.
Actually quite boring, if I was to be totally honest.\nIt was only 79p thankfully, but yeah, made me sleepy zzzZZZZ *snore*

reviewText: Not bad. Simple and very nice at the same time
Where am I going what am I doing what the ♥♥♥♥

This has been quite an experience.  I wasn't expecting nearly so much out of a little game I picked up on a whim.

According to walkthroughs, Kairo can be finished in just a half an hour if you know what you're doing, but I spent hours going through it.  The puzzles are indeed difficult at times, but what slowed me down the most was just stopping to gawk at the architecture.  It's just simple geometry and the textures are concrete, concrete and more concrete, yet somehow it's really amazing to look at.  The intense colored lighting and sheer emptiness of the massive, enigmatic spaces you get to wander through really hit with impact.  What really makes the environment pull you in though is the music.  Kairo has by far some of the best ambient background music I've ever heard.  Definitely play with good headphones if you've get 'em.  I'm officially starting my Steam category of games to go back and play again when the Oculus Rift comes out.

It's really difficult to describe the unique feeling and atmosphere of Kairo's world, but here's the best I can do:  Does anyone remember the bizarre, abstract and often borderline incoherent art-house style computer animation that occasionally showed up on TV in the late 80s and early 90s?  It's like that, but with more thinking.

Gameplay consists mostly of puzzles and exploration, and both are quite rewarding.  A lot of the puzzle give that sort of Myst vibe at first glance (ie. here are some random shapes and levers
date: have fun and see you in a couple hours")  but I found all of them to be fair and some were even a bit intuitive.  There were several that seemed totally abstract like they should have been frustrating to figure out
recommended: and I'm not sure if I just got lucky but the answers always clicked in my head after a bit of twiddling.  With so many puzzle types being redone to death in adventure games
hoursPlayed: it's good to see some totally new concepts that work.  My only real gripe with the puzzles are the fake ones.  Or at least apparently fake ones; I'm really not sure.  There were several rooms I faffed about in for ages before pulling up the in-game hint system to find out the room was just "here to play around with
voteText: mostly."  Mostly?  That's just lovely.  There were two places I recall getting this "hint"
helpfulPercent: and they were the only two places I had to resort to using the hint system.  And then the hint is basically "this room is just here to waste your time. OR IS IT?"  Oh just ♥♥♥♥ off and tell me

Atmospheric game in which you are trying to activate all the machinery.  The puzzles are good, and except for one special puzzle, they were solvable from the game.  Some were easier than others.  Very interesting look.  Took me around 6 hours to complete the entire game.

The game has very bad performance for its pretty mediocre graphics. Also, I understand it's an exploration game, but there is just nothing to the game apart from that. You just walk around mindlessly. There is no real story, no substance and nothing to keep you interested in progressing in the game.

So, Kairo. Who are we?\n\nLove children of turn of the century, cubist 3d rendering and island based exploration games? Retro-Future gazing, pre-VR, post-apocalypse lumbering hulk puzzlers? Half the time, with you, I am unaware if you are even puzzeling me at all. Baby I ain't saying your puzzles are obtuse, but when you give me a momentary, fleeting UI, well, baby, I'm as surprised as the YouTube kitten finding out the cake really was a lie. But we can work this out. I wanna know your secrets. Just tell me. Baby just tell me the next 7 and a half hours are going to really rock me, baby. We can make this work.

First person atmospheric puzzle game with a heavy dash of video game hipster.\n\nI personally love games like this and Kairo didn't disappoint. The atmosphere is very engrossing, from the otherworldly simplistic visuals to the mysterious soundtrack. Well worht it for the price point of $8.

This is definitely one of the prettiest games on Steam, not because of high quality textures or models, but because of the sheer simplicity of it's presentation. It has a lovely soundtrack which you can listen to on Spotify, and every room and puzzle is something to remember. This game also has a good story if you dig deep enough (it took some reading and guides for me). All that said though, some of the puzzles are frustrating (I'm looking at you Einstein room), but the hint system doesn't leave you hanging.\nIf you like adventure games and abstract art, I'd give this game a try.

This is a pretty engaging exploration game. I can recommend it for a low price. It kept me entertained for a day.\nThe atmosphere is superbly crafted. Puzzles are not particularly challenging - it is very much an atmospheric exploration game.

reviewText: This game made me feel like I was in an Arthur C. Clarke novel, exploring weird, alien archetecture.  The atmosphere is fantastic and the design is excellent.  Everything (including the interface) is elegant and stripped-down.  I was surprised at how many distinct, memorable places could be made from such simple building blocks.  The puzzles are engaging, but not very difficult; for me, the game was paced exactly right, with no area wearing out its welcome before I was able to move on and see something new.

A very good puzzle game in an avant garde world. Artifacts and symbols found in it give you the creepy sensation that this world might be tied to our own, or an analogue to it. I completed the game, got all but two secrets found, and thought it well worth the money.\n\nThere is no death, no time limit, only I'm stuck at this puzzle" and "hey I found a secret" to this game."

Intresting artstyle, relativly challenging puzzels, (not so Challenging as MYST but good). It also has a no descript story and strong message in it. Worth getting if its on special but probably wouldn't pay full price for it due to its short gametime (~2 hours), however plenty of secrets to find in it.
Pretty simple but quite nice. Kills boredom for a few hours.
An incredible puzzle game. The ending makes the entire ambient, vaguely unsettling experience of a trek worthwhile. An absolute steal for $5.
Nice adventure puzzler.  Completely in vane of Myst yet even more abstract.  No explicit allusions to what is actually going on....you must infer.\n\nGood puzzles and some good secrets.

This game didn't take too long to finish, but somehow I managed to wait for months in between sessions and forget what was going on.  So I would NOT do that, were I to live life a second time.

This game has a few REALLY killer puzzles, and I am a snob about puzzles, so that is saying something.  I think the number one thing that made this game work is it's utter abstractness.  Many of the best puzzles were fairly simple tasks, but understanding how the mechanisms worked was a challending and engaging task, simply because of the lack of context.

One of the most interesting and unique things about this game is the cool control scheme in which the position where you are standing affects the state of the world.  This is used in a variety of ways, and it somehow manages to make very simple puzzles a lot more engaging.

On the down side, this game was definitely lacking in polish.  Movement was slightly glitchy - especially going up stairs and jumping off walls (which I'm not sure you were supposed to be able to do at all).  There were often cheap looking cracks between blocks that didn't quite touch.  Some icons looked like poorly clipped .pngs.  Just a little rough around the edges.

Also the story" kept getting devastatingly interesting
date: and then leaving you hanging.  Ending was super weird (secret ending was even weirder.  But no

reviewText:
Very original and challenging puzzle game. As you start exploring the world you're in and start solving puzzles you will start gathering pieces of information on WHAT on earth you're actually doing all this for. VERY atmospheric game with some serious creepyness at times.
Some puzzles rely on speed, many rely on observational skills and hardly any of them are easily solved.

The game also has a secret bonus ending that requires the collection of 18 hidden runes and the destruction of 3 very well hidden monoliths. I had 8/18 and 0/3 after finishing the game, so I wasn't even close to getting it.

Highly recommended if you like games that focus on puzzles, atmosphere, mystery, exploration and a little creepyness.

This is a good game, but if your save messes up it's a bit frustrating. Make sure you're always saving. The modern take is awesome, and the concepts are cool. Defintely for a person who loves puzzle exploration games.

Kario falls into what I state as the Abstract Genere. In a nutshell, what I define as an Abstract game is that it is simplistic but means something more that what it is, usually parred up with another genere. Examples of what I mean can be games like English Country Tune and Antichamber.

At first everything was straight forward, step on button A to make event B happen. After that, puzzles start to require TONS of observation, so non-observent people will get shot down. I ended using many hints near the end of the game.

Even at times, you had to overthink things, like square -> square means 4 -> 4.

Overall, it is an Abstract puzzle game that requires deep thinking at times. Also 6.28318530717958...

My one complaint is that it doesn't really tell you at all what you're doing, so you're left fumbling around trying to solve whatever puzzles it gives you. But some might say that's a good thing, and I can see where they're coming from. My rating for this game: 8/10.
A great game experience.  You look you move.  You solve puzzles.  Very minimal and artistic.  The audio is VERY well done.

I loved the fact that you don't have an action button it's just good old fashion pushing or jumping on. It's a small detail, but still, it's not usual and I think it brings something unique to this game.

Also the visuals, I loved them, but I also loved the images in the steam store page, here's a tip: the visuals are right there, you don't get a LOT more than that, it's all squares and different colors, if you don't like the images you might not like the visuals in the game.

Highly recommended if you are into Adventure genre. This is for Myst what Guernica" is for "Mona Lisa"

reviewText:
There are two ways to approach Kairo. The first is to view it as a meditative experience in an open world with many soothing  environments and lots of exploration. The second view is to see it as a string of puzzles that need to be solved to complete and beat the game.

You'll enjoy it either way you view it. If you decide to explore, you will see many different areas, and come to love the fact that you can hide away in the world of Kairo and relax after a long day. Walk around in the Park, look at the alien structures, and relax to the calm sounds of water rushing, or birds chirping.


And if you take it as a string of puzzles, you will be challenged with a system with no interaction button, with clues to guide you when you are lost. You will push things, pull things, and eventually get the machines that govern the world of Kairo running.

And be treated to a delightful and uplifting ending.
I have no words other than amazing" to describe this game. Beautiful
recommended: and awe inspiring.\n\nWould be glad to buy it at full price any day
hoursPlayed: very much worth it."

reviewText: Stark environments and fun puzzles. I really enjoyed the abstract presentation.

What do Portal, Antichamber, Quantum Conundrum, and...oh hell, why not...Bad Rats have in common?

They are all puzzle games (in some sense), yet they all have character to them, something that brings charm to an otherwise incredibly dull game.

Kairo, on the other hand, has absolutely no character in its' floating stone architecture. I wandered the halls looking for some storyline or meaning to my progress, yet there's absolutely nothing to keep your interest for longer than 10 minutes (except possibly for the achievements). Not even Kairo's architecture is interesting, resembling the surreal cubic design of Assassin's Creed's Animus with all the life sucked out of them.

The game doesn't even redeem itself on its' puzzles, which are ridiculously simple and generic, and yet are still explained in full within the game's hint menu.

I only spent $0.82, and yet I still feel like I wasted my money. Save up and buy a better puzzle/platformer instead.
Fun with three dimensional blocks in muted colors and that is about it.
I felt like I was playing The Stanley Parable" crossed with Serious Sam: The First Encounter. If you like sounds of extreme terror

Kario falls into what I state as the Abstract Genere. In a nutshell, what I define as an Abstract game is that it is simplistic but means something more that what it is, usually parred up with another genere. Examples of what I mean can be games like English Country Tune and Antichamber.

At first everything was straight forward, step on button A to make event B happen. After that, puzzles start to require TONS of observation, so non-observent people will get shot down. I ended using many hints near the end of the game.

Even at times, you had to overthink things, like square -> square means 4 -> 4.

Overall, it is an Abstract puzzle game that requires deep thinking at times. Also 6.28318530717958...

An excellent game for the price, I highly recommend it!

From the moment the game begins to the ending sequence, Kairo's atmosphere remains powerful and unique. The world feels vast and lonely, but far from empty. The world is strange and yet eerily familiar, and the puzzles keep you involved in the goal. You can spend hours exploring the numerous rooms, each with its own atmosphere and function.\nVery simple controls stop you from playing the guessing game on how to interact with things, so that the focus can be on the environment and puzzles that surround you. The music and atmospheric sounds add to the vast and lonely feeling of the world, and some elements you come across can send shivers down your spine.\nIf you're one for getting lost in an atmosphere, this is a game for you.
One of the most fantastic and engaging indie games I have ever played.

Kairo is a puzzle exploration game. You travel the world of Kairo, trying to move forward and get to the next door… and the next… and the next.

The graphics are simple – smooth and coloured walls will keep you company. It gives the game a cold and sinister feel. I felt small and lost, running around in large buildings, trying to get out.


You have no inventory, no set of tools to help you out. Instead you unlock your surroundings by how and where you move and what you do. It’s a very unnerving and immersive experience.

It is difficult to explain this game without saying too much. But playing Kairo, I felt like I was the last person in the world, trying desperately to find my way out of a complex I was not meant to be in. If you like first-person explorations games, you should play this one.

7/10

“It seems to me there is so much more to the world than the average eye is allowed to see. I believe if you look hard, there are more wonders in this universe than you could ever have dreamed of. It's colour! Colour that holds the key! I can hear the colours, listen to them. Every time I step outside, I feel nature is shouting at me. Come on! Come and get me! Come on! Capture my mystery!”\n– Vincent van Gogh to the Eleventh Doctor

Okay, let's get one thing out of the way first: this game does not look good. The trailer above kinda oversells the graphics — they're not minimalistic, they're cheap.
That being said, everything else about Kairo is great.

Distant cousin of Myst, this game is comprised mostly of puzzles. And there is a compelling diversity in these: some are very easy, some are very difficult; some totally straightforward, some mind-bendingly abstract; and of course everything in between. This makes the progression always enticing and never boring.
The level design is very cool despite the poor graphics and each level has its own unique feel, the whole game being very atmospheric". This is brilliantly reinforced by the marvelous sound design

reviewText: A short but interesting puzzle and exploration game. The puzzles are mostly intuitive, and there's a hint series for each room if you get stuck, which I greatly appreciated. The graphics are simple blocky 3D, but the art style is fascinating, with huge elaborate temple complexes and imposing architecture. There isn't any real story (until you start looking into the secret ending), which just helps the overall dreamlike feeling of the game. If you like exploration and puzzles, this game should be worth your time.

While Kairo may appear incredibly strange and weird to some, it is a great example of minimalistic puzzle-based gameplay in a minimalistic world with a minimalistic story. Very little is explained to you, and very little needs explanation. This is a game that I prefer to see as a playable dream.

If you enjoy like wandering around in cool environments and solving challenging yet simple puzzles this game is for you. It is exactly what it says in the description, and doesn't try to be anything else.\nIt can take awhile to 100% it though, since one of the extras is bugged (hence, why I spent so long on it trying to figure out how to get the last achievements).\nOther than that though it was an enjoyable experience if you like atmosphere, puzzles, and a vague, interpertive story.

If you're anything like me, Kairo has caught your interest because of its visual style, but you're not quite sure what you're getting here.  The trailer is vague, and users have tagged it with potentially worrisome labels like Abstract" and "Walking Simulator."  It looks interesting
date: but is it a game or an art piece?\n\nIt's both.  If you're unsure
recommended: let me reassure you that Kairo is most certainly a game

voteText: but the puzzles themselves are generally quite logical in nature.\n\nYou might be disoriented at first

votesHelpful: so check it out.  As you start to wander through the structure

reviewText: I bought this looking for a pure exploration/discovery game, was not disappointed. Fantastic game.

Very original and challenging puzzle game. As you start exploring the world you're in and start solving puzzles you will start gathering pieces of information on WHAT on earth you're actually doing all this for. VERY atmospheric game with some serious creepyness at times.
Some puzzles rely on speed, many rely on observational skills and hardly any of them are easily solved.

The game also has a secret bonus ending that requires the collection of 18 hidden runes and the destruction of 3 very well hidden monoliths. I had 8/18 and 0/3 after finishing the game, so I wasn't even close to getting it.

Highly recommended if you like games that focus on puzzles, atmosphere, mystery, exploration and a little creepyness.

Kairo is a great little game with really nice logic puzzles that aren't too difficult but requires some thinking. The game hints at a story but it's very vague and it could just as well have no story. The thing I really loved about Kairo was the atmosphere it created, it made me feel very isolated and small because the levels were usually very big and empty and it had a very minimalist environment. The atmosphere got creepy at times as things such as static on the screen would flare up and number station recordings would play as you got closer to certain areas. The game always had me questioning things, because sometimes strange objects or symbols would be around and it would make me want to know why they were there or what they meant. I also liked the ambient music as that too helped with the atmosphere and it fits right into the game.
So weird. Sooooo weird. I beat it and I was like what? how? when? and it was strange and beautiful.

Kairo is surprisingly immersive for a first-person puzzler; in fact, it is surreal enough to be creepy. Surreal aesthetics aside, the game offers enough mind-bending challenges to keep you busy for a while.

If you're anything like me, Kairo has caught your interest because of its visual style, but you're not quite sure what you're getting here.  The trailer is vague, and users have tagged it with potentially worrisome labels like Abstract" and "Walking Simulator."  It looks interesting
date: but is it a game or an art piece?\n\nIt's both.  If you're unsure
recommended: let me reassure you that Kairo is most certainly a game
hoursPlayed: and it's a pretty good one if you like puzzlers.  The environment might be abstract
voteText: but the puzzles themselves are generally quite logical in nature.\n\nYou might be disoriented at first
helpfulPercent: though.  Kairo starts by dropping you into its world without any pretext.  Why are you here and what are your goals?  The game doesn't tell you.  There's a building to explore in front of you
votesHelpful: so check it out.  As you start to wander through the structure
votesTotal: you'll find rooms with elements you can interact with in various ways.  Maybe there's a block you can push or a switch you can activate.  Maybe there's a navigational challenge.\n\nKairo is designed so that you can generally deduce what needs to be done in some way.  For example
votesFunny: there might be pictorial clues
commentsCount: or you might notice how something in the environment is responding to what you are doing.  The game also makes good use of sound cues to guide you
column16: with clears tones to suggest success or failure.  If all else fails
column17: the pause menu gives you access to three hints per puzzle
column18: and there's no penalty for using them.   Some areas don't include a puzzle
column19: and the hint menu can also be useful for determining as much.  If there aren't any hints
column20: the area doesn't have a puzzle to solve.\n\nI very much enjoyed Kairo
column21: but one thing that surprised me about it is how relentlessly eerie it is.  A lot of this comes down to the sound design.  Upon being booted up
column22: the game credits someone who refers to himself as "Wounds" with doing the music
column23: so that gives you some idea of what to expect.  The game sounds like it's been scored by a ghost
column24: but that only aids its immersion factor.  Also
column25: while Kairo doesn't have a traditional narrative
column26: there are occasional clues to what's going on littered around and the game world.  Some of what you find can be ominous.\n\nI do have one major gripe with the game.  The main puzzles play fairly with you
column27: but there are a few optional puzzles that are pretty ludicrous.  You don't need to solve these puzzles to beat the game
column28: but some of the achievements are tied up with them.  If you are a completionist
column29: expect to use a guide on at least one or two of these if you come back to solve them.  I'm not kidding.  One of the optional puzzles in particular is essentially out of bounds.\n\nAll in all
column31: this is a solid recommendation from me if most of what I've said sounds good to you.  Kairo is fully worth its full $5 price
column32: and you definitely shouldn't hesitate if it's on sale."

reviewText: Stark environments and fun puzzles. I really enjoyed the abstract presentation.

As an abstract puzzle game, Kairo is great.  The gameplay is simple yet challenging, and the built-in hint system is helpful enough to point you in the right direction when you're stuck without outright spoiling the puzzle.  However, I think the abstract design makes the story hard to follow (and leaves the player to guess); after finishing the game, I wasn't really sure what it was all about.  Still, that doesn't detract from the gameplay.  If you enjoy puzzle games and want something a little different, I would definitely recommend Kairo.

Pros:
- Otherworldly/alien environment.
- Engaging, abstract, and unique puzzles.
- Good music, which helps set a somewhat ominous and somber tone.

Cons:
- The story was a little *too* abstract.
- Keyboard controls are not remappable, or even listed in full.  For example, the R" key resets you to the room entrance
date: but I found that completely by accident.\n- There is no way to see your progress on collecting the hidden glyphs
recommended: except by collecting more of the glyphs.  I would like to have seen my current progress when the game is paused (such as how the map is displayed)."

reviewText: As some of the reviewers say, Kairo is... odd. It feels a bit like exploring the inside of someone's mind.\n\nI found it fascinating.
Simple, yet intericate, I highly recommend it for the puzzles.

First things first KAIRO is a straight up Puzzler.
It isn't really anything else, especially barely a game of exploration.
What i think is really good in that regard is that it doesn't seem to lock you into a puzzle.


There is somewhat of an part exploration in the gameplay but it doesn't really reward you for it.
Yes, i know you can find some kind of runes, however that isn't really what i want to be rewarded with when it comes to exploration.

What i want from exploring a world is interesting and inspiring sites and views and in that regard Kairo is rather weak.


One reason why i feel that way is simply taste. :-P
The overall world design is far to abstrcat for my taste,
The structures in Kairo simply feel to artificial wich leads to me thinking well
recommended: intersting design dear gamedesigner" instead of loosing myself in the world and inspiring thougths like "what may have happened here" or "i wonder what this once was".\nOn top of that many elements of the world look really rather unfitting in their surroundings instead of giving me the feeling that they are a naturall part of this structures.
hoursPlayed:
The design simply lacks a conclusive and whole overall direction.

The second reason is that Kairo is really rather crude and unpolished.
Don't get too close to the walls becasue the camera will clip trough the walls.
Strange lighting effects that most likely weren't suppossed to be there or even look like the textures have been placed wrong are visible in the VERY FIRST rooms you will explore in the game.

But the worst are the textures overall. They look really
voteText:
really HORRIBBLE!
It really pulls you out of the experience if you can count the pixels of what is suppossed to be cracks and holes in walls.

The second weakness is Kairos Sonddesign or rather the lack thereoff. There are sounds and noises but they are more annoying then enriching and in many places sounds simply a re missing where there should have been some noice.
If giant structures in the world are moving i shouldn't feel like they are made of Styrophor and have no weight to them. Wich is exactly what happens in Kairo.

Kairo wants to be a minimalist thing but minimalistic doesn't mean low quality of assets and i feel that is what has been confused here when Kairo was designed.

Would i recommend it?

Nah

not really.

Kairo wants to achieve in a far better and much more polished way.

reviewText: Game is ok

I love love love this game. Although this game has a vague story as well as (mostly) strictly geometrical graphics, Kairo use both to its advantage. If you gather the little symbols around the game, it rewards you with a hidden scene. They help answer some questions while also possibly leaving you with more, yet you also get a lot of room to interpret what's happened to the world you come from and the purpose of the world you currently inhabit. The story /is/ quite minimalistic however.\nI'm a fan of very abstract trippy scenes, and Kairo has a lot of them. Despite the simple shapes that Kairo is constructed of, the creator really did a good job with making the environments interesting. A really strong point in Kairo is the environment coupled with the use of sound. I really love the strangeness that the sound adds to the atmosphere. There are several structures in Kairo that emit static, random arrays of numbers, and other strange noises.\nAnyway. Yes, I recomend the game. if you like casual exploration and trippy areas to explore, you'll like it.

This game wasn't really one of my favorites. There was a sizeable portion where I just wanted it to end. The puzzles were interesting and fun to complete. Everything in between kind of just blurred together into a multi-colored swatch of concrete. This game is not pretty. A sizeable portion of it I couldn't even enjoy artisticly. It felt like I was walking through some one's grad school project. The symbols throughout the game felt forced. It all just felt a little bit too obvious to me. Maybe that's just me. I just didn't like it. I appreciate what the game is trying to do, and I can tell a lot of love went into this. I just don't think I was the right audience for this one. I will say the secret ending was awesome. That quite possibly was worth going through the game to get. If stark modern art is your kind of thing then this game is right up your alley. If you aren't into that kind of thing you might want to try something else.
I did a lot of walking, did a lot of things. I'm not sure where I was walking, nor what the things I did actually achieved, but I did it. Would recommend if you like puzzles and confusing landscape.

This is a pretty interesting game. Though oftentimes it suffers from the same problem as similar indie titles. It'll forget it's an abstract first person puzzle game and become Sculpture Garden Simulator 2015. Yes game, when walk through your rooms I appreciate your post-modernist, minimalist design that recalls Egyptian, Chinese and Classical art. But when you place these puzzle-less rooms in between the puzzles, you're really hurting the pacing. Though for $0.74 (as of this writing) , I definitely recommend picking it up. The puzzles are just challenging enough and if you have trouble the game has a pretty generous hint system.
just a black screen... i tried deleting and redownloading.. still a black screen. fix please i actually want to play this game.

Kairo is beautiful, plain and simple. It is an adventure from the begining. Not because of the adrenaline injections most games rely on and many gamers are addicted to. Everything is so carefully placed as to invoke a sense of haunting and ancient beauty. The game reminds me of a ghost story. Your character is in search of a ghost (let's say the ghost of his wife.) His search has led him to the ancient temple where all spirits reside. He must return life to all of the spirits in the temple to find his wife. Bad fanfiction aside, this game is pure genius and I want all of my friends to play it.

If you're a myst fan then this will be right up your alley. Stepping out into to the monolithic environments of Kairo is akin to stepping out onto that dock in myst for the first time. Kairo is able to conjur up an atmosphere of loneliness and mystery that really sticks with you the whole game. While basically a walking simulator, there where times that I was simply awestruck by the towering structures and deep shadows the dominate its barren landscape. Aparrently it has oculus support as well, which put this first on the list of things i'm going to play when I finally have the funds to join the VR club. Kairo is also a very decent puzzler, requiring you to pay close attencion to your surroundings in order to peice everything together. While a few of the puzzles can get rather abstract, I never found myself stuck becuase of a handy hint system you can use to cheat if ever need be. For the price you can get it at, this game delivers a unique experience that you won't find anywhere else. I'd highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys atmosphere and immersion, and doesn't mind being stumped by a puzzle from time to time.
If you have the patience for a small amount of backtracking and have a love for disturbing soundtracks, by all means, go for it.

This game features an engaging storyline, unusual puzzles and one point in particular in the graphical part.\nThere was a geometrization of forms and volumes, different perspectives, monochromatic colors. This reminded me the Pablo Picasso arts, the Cubist art in general.

This first-person puzzle game relies on a minimalist, surreal environment to pull you in...but boy does it deliver.  I think if you liked Myst, you'll like this game...wandering around a vast, abandoned landscape fiddling with technology you don't understand.  But the game's not about the fiddling...it's about the wandering and the discovery (you'll know what to fiddle when the time comes).  If you like exploring and the visual style appeals to you (watch the video) then definitely pick this up.\n\nI'm going to come back and flesh out this review more, but for now, I want to make a note of the fact that the coolest thing about Kairo, for me, was the ambience of the environments.  It was quite Myst-like in that it created this constant sense of wonder at the surreal landscapes.

Smart, unusual, inventive and weirdly beautiful. The atmosphere is captivating, every room is distinctive and fun to explore, puzzles are smart, not too hard, and interesting to solve. The entire experience is really well-paced and the background music closes the deal.  Definetely a YES for anybody who digs a different kind of game every once in a while.

I very much enjoyed this game.  There is not enough like this out there.  The game felt very personal, and there was something about the world that kept you exploring.  The atmosphere was wonderful, and it transports you away to this strange and bizarre world.  The conclusion of the game kept me thinking for a while as to the meaning of the game, and I came to a few conclusions.  That is what makes this a good game, it can be interpreted in many different ways.  I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys more atmospheric games with mild puzzle solving elements.  Some of the puzzles are very difficult, there is still one that I cannot solve.  The most difficult puzzles are the ones that really demand you to pay attention to your environment.
I would prefer to have my eyes sewn shut than look at this beautiful game again.

IMPORTANT: When you hit the normal ending, wait for the credits to play out. They're not long.

Wow.

Kairo is absolutely stellar. It is ominous, confusing, ethereal, gorgeous, and fascinating.

The whole time you play, you're kept curious and driven to discover what is going on, and how all the pieces fit together.

The minimalistic design just serves to heighten the sense that this is a strange and alien place. The music, performed by Wounds, lends much of the foreboding nature to the feel of the environments.

There is one puzzle that feels artificially difficult and out of place, but the rest are really organic and are wonderful to solve.

Absolutely worth a play through.

A really atmospheric puzzle and exploration game.  I was very impressed with how the environment and your interactions with it tells the narrative.  I found myself crawling all over the areas in this game.  I really like its style.  Very mysterious and unsettling thanks to the excellent soundtrack.

I did it again! Game has intresting immersive world and good a little disturbing atmosphere. Kind of similar to Myst, but... You need to see! Great Soundtrack! It is definietly worth spend couple of hours with. It also seems like developer fixes all bugs and made achievements work.

The puzzles are pretty simple most of the time and can be solved by observing your surroundings. The game lasts for ~3 hours (if you get the glyphs and stuff). If you're into a short, interesting adventure, grab it.

This game feels like a dream, with a haunting soundtrack and an atmosphere of mystery that makes the hairs on your back rise even on the warmest summer day. Puzzles are easy enough, so you can just sit back and enjoy the journey that it takes you on. Shame it isn't a longer experience, but in line with its minimalistic graphics it has all the core gameplay and none of the bulk.

Walk about, solve a puzzle and things happen that let you progress. In the meanwhile you notice eerie things in the areas; whether that be the outline of a head on a fuzzy screen, or a picture of Albert Einstein. I will admit that at some points of the game you are going to feel uncomfortable. There were some moments when I had shivers down my spine. When a game can make you feel this way without the need for jumpscares, it has done good.\nThe backstory? In my opinoin, Kairo is an okay game. It tries to blend confusion and beauty, but ends up being a mess. Some puzzles are easy to solve, but others have no direction and are almost unsolvable if it weren't for google and the fourms.

First, I'll start off with the puzzles. As I said, some are good brainteasers or just require good reflexes, but some made absolutely no sense. Sometimes I find myself scrambling around the current area looking for clues and hidden messages when the only task I have is to walk forward. Often, I find hidden messages that have no meaning, and I end up trying to figure out the purpose. Some harder puzzles had me pulling my hair out in frustration, which, in my opinion is okay. The problem is that I end up resorting to Google or the fourms for answers.

Often, puzzles only reward you with more puzzles, sometimes harder, and sometimes easier. The difficulty in this game seems to be spontaneous, which is a mystery on its own. A lot of rooms have you walking for what seems like an eternity before giving you a clue, forcing you to glide back to the beginning and solve it.

reviewText: Lovely game with some incredibly cryptic visuals and music.

Okay, let's get one thing out of the way first: this game does not look good. The trailer above kinda oversells the graphics — they're not minimalistic, they're cheap.
That being said, everything else about Kairo is great.

Distant cousin of Myst, this game is comprised mostly of puzzles. And there is a compelling diversity in these: some are very easy, some are very difficult; some totally straightforward, some mind-bendingly abstract; and of course everything in between. This makes the progression always enticing and never boring.
The level design is very cool despite the poor graphics and each level has its own unique feel, the whole game being very atmospheric". This is brilliantly reinforced by the marvelous sound design

reviewText: A short but interesting puzzle and exploration game. The puzzles are mostly intuitive, and there's a hint series for each room if you get stuck, which I greatly appreciated. The graphics are simple blocky 3D, but the art style is fascinating, with huge elaborate temple complexes and imposing architecture. There isn't any real story (until you start looking into the secret ending), which just helps the overall dreamlike feeling of the game. If you like exploration and puzzles, this game should be worth your time.

In the first half hour of my play i made almost 0 progress...
